titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Samuel Halperin Puck and Judge cartoon collection, 1879-1903 MS2121
titlestmt.author: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

publicationstmt.publisher: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2022-05-18 14:30:14 -0400.

repository.corpname: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

did.unittitle: Samuel Halperin Puck and Judge cartoon collection
did.abstract: This collection contains nineteenth century political cartoons. The collection includes illustrations from issues of "Puck" for the years 1879-1903 and illustrations of "Judge" for the years 1887-1900. Undated illustrations for both magazines are also included. The subject matters of these illustrations are broadly popular culture, history, journalism, and politics.

prefercite.head: Preferred citation
prefercite.p: Samuel Halperin Puck and Judge cartoon collection, Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: This collection was donated by Samuel Halperin.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use
userestrict.p: Some material may be copyrighted or restricted. It is the patron's obligation to determine and satisfy copyright or other case restrictions when publishing or otherwise distributing materials found in the collections.

bioghist.head: Historical or Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Both "Puck" and "Judge" were weekly magazines during the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries. "Puck" was founded by Joseph Keppler, a Viennese immigrant to the United States. The staff included, at various times, artists such as F. Graetz, Karl Elder von Stur, Frederick Opper, James A. Wales, Bernard Gilliam, Eugene Zimmerman, Louis Dalrymple, C.J. Taylor, Frank A. Nankivell, Louis M. Glackens, J.S. Pughe, and Joseph Keppler, Jr. "Judge" was founded by former "Puck" illustrator James A. Wales, who sold the magazine in 1885 to William J. Arkell. Arkell managed to lure Bernard Gilliam from "Puck" and made him a full partner at "Judge." By the first World War, news magazines like "Puck" and "Judge" were unable to compete with the demands and popularity of the daily newspaper.
[the following book was used to prepare this note: "The Ungentlemanly Art." by Stephen Hess and Milton Kaplan]

scopecontent.head: Collection Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This collection contains nineteenth century political cartoons. The collection includes illustrations from issues of "Puck" for the years 1879-1903 and illustrations of "Judge" for the years 1887-1900. Undated illustrations for both magazines are also included. The subject matters of these illustrations are broadly popular culture, history, journalism, and politics.
This collection was donated by Dr. Samuel Halperin in 1995.

arrangement.head: Collection Organization
arrangement.p: Organized into three series: Illustrations from "Puck" and Illustrations from "Judge."

odd.head: Collection note
odd.p: Formerly Graphic Coll #10. The following biography is about the donor and is from the original finding aid: Dr. Samuel Halperin, who received his doctorate in Political Science from Washington University (St. Louis) in 1956, has held a variety of leadership positions in academia, the federal government, and non-profit organizations. As a congressional Fellow of the American Political Science Association, he worked on U.S. Senate and House of Representatives committees that dealt with major education legislation (1960-61). As Director of the U.S. Office of Education's Office of Congressional Relations and, later, as Assistant U. S. Commissioner of Education for Legislation, he participated in development and passage of such significant measures as the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 and the Higher Education Acts of 1963 and 1965. In 1966, Dr. Halperin joined the Office of the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare where, as Deputy Assistant Secretary under Secretaries John W. Gardner and Wilbur J. Cohen, he continued work as an executive branch he was twice awarded HEW's Superior Service Award lobbyist" for passage of scores of Great Society measures in education and the social services. For these efforts

did.unittitle: Illustrations from "Puck"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains nineteenth century political cartoons for the years 1879-1903. The subject matters of these illustrations are broadly popular culture, history, journalism, and politics.

"In the Heyday of Youth."Uncle Ephriam.-Young Bige Tompkins is goin; ter teach the Burdock school, an' Lazarus Mickle is takin' a daily paper, an' Peg Barclow's boy is writin' the Corncob Corners items fer the Frogeye Bulwark of Liberty.Uncle Ebenezer.-Beats all! It gits plainer every day that this is truly the "young man's age."
"Intoxicated With His Own Glory."His Supports are Giving Way-Can He Stand Alone?
"The Irish Land Question."
"The Irrestible Magnet.-A Counter Attraction to New Year's Good Resolves."
"Is Marriage a Failure?"Yes; in this case.

"A Never Ending `Job.' "Puck.-Gentlemen, it seems to me you have few workmen for such a big bridge.BROOKLYN BRIDGE DIRECTORS.-Well, you see, we are waiting for more "steel!"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Full text on illustration: "A Hint To A Long-Suffering People. When Plumbers are fighting each other, oh, then Is a possible chance for respectable men; Let us hang them together, both 'Union' and 'Rats,' And hope for the fate of the Kilkenny cats."

did.unittitle: "Johnny's Ambitions, And How They Were Not Realized."
"A Political Mother-Goose Melody."

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Full text on illustration: "A Political Mother-Goose Melody. Pussy's in the Well! Who Put Her In? - We Regret to Say: 'T was the Naughty Republi-kin. Who'll Come Forward and Take Out the Cat? - 'Why, I Will, with Pleasure,' Says the Good Democrat."

did.unittitle: "A Heavy Load To Carry."
"In The Political Arena.-The Biggest Bag Wins."
"The Metropolitan Museum."

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Full text on illustration: "The Metropolitan Museum. 'It is intended as much for the humblest artisan as for the most refined lover of the fine arts.'-Henry G. Marquand' And this is how the workingman enjoys the Museum on his only day of liberty.-Puck."

did.unittitle: "At It Again. Uncle Sam (to N.Y. Sensation Press).-Calm down, Sonny-you couldn't kill the World's Fair, and you can't scare me!"
"Jealousy Makes Him Ridiculous. He Vents His Spite Against The Chicago Fair Because It Excels His Own Effort Of 1889."
"A Revelation In Revolutions. Uncle Sam.-Well! Well! You boys have at last had a revolution which will help the whole world."
"A Tough Job For The Atlas Of The Labor World. Henry George.- If you fellows up there don't keep quiet, I shall have to drop the whole thing!"
"Free America."

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Full text on illustration: "Free America. Chorus of Skilled Foreigners.-why are we not allowed to land, when those over there are received with open arms? Official-The law lets them fellers in because they didn't come over under contract; an'it keep you out because you did."

did.unittitle: "In Danger."
"Expensive Blowing In Congress. Come, ye gas-bags, both blue and gray,-Start yourselves on your homeward way."
Unknown Title, illustration of assemblyman dancing on New York.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Text on illustration: "Oh, I am a rural assembyman, From Wayback County fair, With no conscience at all, and one ounce of brains, And the hayseed in my hair. And I dance all over New York's proud town, With a foot as heavy as Fate; I levy her taxes and pocket my bribes, And New York must pay the freight."

odd.p: Full text on illustration: "Noxious Growths In Libery's Grounds. Uncle Sam.-Hello, Puck, are you 'up a tree'? - - Puck.-No, but you will be if you don't clear this stuff out pretty soon!"

did.unittitle: "The Night Before Christmas-An Unnecessary Call."

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Full text on illustration: "The Night Before Christmas-An Unnecessary Call. Santa Claus.-This is getting to be too extravagant for me! I guess I'll go where I'm more needed."

did.unittitle: "The Modern Wandering Jew."

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Full text on illustration: "The Modern Wandering Jew. A fated wanderer, his way he wends, Driven here and there by many selfish friends; Where'er he goes, sign of a people's wrath, The Curse of the Third Term still haunts his path."

did.unittitle: "He Won't Have It."

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Full text on illustration: "He Won't Have It. The Greatest Living Mis-Statesman.-Trusts are largely private affairs. The Greatest Living Carnegie.-The public may regard Trusts with serene confidence. Uncle Sam.-Silence, you apologists for Robbery! or I'll give you a dose of 'Triumphant Democracy' that you won't like!"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Full text on illustration: "Working On The Sympathies Of The Jury. This Sort of Thing has Gone So Far Already, that We Might as Well Do the Family Tableau Business Up in Systematic Style, for the Benefit of out Distinguished Criminals."

odd.head: General note

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Full text on illustration: Thanksgiving. Uncle Sam.-"Well, we seem to be getting along a little bettern than the rest of the world, and if we can't be thankful for all that we have, we may at least be thankful that thre are som things which we haven't.' "

odd.p: Full text on illustration: "Puck.-Aha! I'll let the people know that the pension-sharks are trying to make a stalking-horse of the Grand Army Organization!"

did.unittitle: "Let Us Have A Good Bankruptcy Law, As A Protection Against The 'Preferred Creditor' Swindle."

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Full text on illustration: "Some 'Children' Of The Present Day. Santa Claus.-'Well, They Don't Seem To Have Much Use For Me! They're Like A Lot Of Little Old Men And Women! If They're Going To Get Like, This, I May As Well Retire From Business!' "

did.unittitle: Unknown Title, Depiction of The World's International Cotton Centennial Exposition from Dec. 1, 1884 to May 31, 1885.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Full text on illustration: "Now Peace hath done her perfect work-serene, Loyal and beautiful, the Southern queen Bids all the wide world welcome to her door, Where Industry has spread a varied store, Where the white splendor of her heaping bales Answers the snow of crowding foreign sales- Wise sister, blessed be thy welcoming hand, Stretched to Republics of the tropic land!"

scopecontent.p: "Faith, and it's on the bottle we'll bring it up - and ourselves, too!"

did.unittitle: Pat's Double Burden
The next reception of the Chinese Embassy The Washington Hog will not take them by surprise again
The Rest Question

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Text on document "Puck to Capitalist: -"Why not build little $1000 Cottages and let them to our Laboring Classes at $12 a mounth, so that they may breathe pure air - it wold be a paying investment?" Capitalists: -"My dear fellow- they wouldn't live in them if I did. Even if they had a lodge oer a Stable or a Gin mill, they won't leave the city!"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Full text on illustration: "Halt! Spirit of The War For The Union.-'Had you gought for those flags, you would not be so quick to give them away!' Cleveleand.-'Great Scott! I thought you were dead and forgotten long ago. I only meant to please Mr. Solid South. They're rubbish anyhow.' "

did.unittitle: "Bringing Free Trade To The Farmer's Door."

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Full text on illustration: "Bringing Free Trade To The Farmer's Door. The Mills Free Trade Bill includes Vegetables, Fruits, Potatoes, Hops, Flax, and Wool. American Farmers.-What shall we do? We cannot compete with European Cheap Labor. English Importer.-Go to Europe and Farm or Starve!"

did.unittitle: "The Nations Favorite. In the Interest of Unity and Harmony, Judge makes a Nomination for 1888 on which all parties would unite."
"Big Blaines Little Enemies. The Democratic Editors resort to all kinds of disreputable means in their attempt to find a bad record for Mr. Blaine as Secretary of State."
"The Last Scene in Uncle Grover's Cabin.-The Death Of Little Eva Democracy."

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Full text for illustration: "The Last Scene In Uncle Grover's Cabin.-The Death Of Little Eva Democracy. 'Put erside d' liddle playt'ings; Lay d' banjo on d' flo: Hush yo' voices down t' nuffin, Liddle Eva's got ter go. All them Doctors tried to pull her Frough d' sickness,-t'warn't no use Pills en braces, yarbs en mixtur's Jes' helped out ter cook her goose."

did.unittitle: "Saints and Sinner-The Split In The Democratic Party."
"On The Hog."
"Free (Trade) Lunch."

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Full text on illustration: "Free (Trade) Lunch. Grover Cleveland prposes to make Free Lunch of the American Workingman's Bread and Cheese, for the benefit of European Pauper Laborers."

did.unittitle: "Foreign Tramps Warned Off!"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Full text on illustration: "Foreign Tramps Warned Off! 'We have happily maintained a policy of avoiding all interference with European affairs. We have a just right to expect that our European policy will be the American policy of European courts. We have a clear right to expect that no European Government will seek to establish colonial dependencies upon the territory of Independent American States. That which a sense of justice restrains us from seeking they may be reasonably expected willingly to forego. We shall neither fail to respect the flag of any friendly nation or the just rights of its citizens, nor to exact the like treatment for our own.' President Harrison's Inauguration Address. Foreign Powers-'By Jingo! another Party has the Place!' "

did.unittitle: "Cleveland, The English Clothier."

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Full text on illustration: "Cleveland, The English Clotheir. Uncle Sam-'This style may do for John Bull, but it doesn't suit me. Ill stick to my old clothes.' Chorus of Anglo-Maniacs - 'Oh! it looks chawming! And it's so English, you know!' "

scopecontent.p: Text on document "John Bull - "Ah! This is the Moses that will open the American Land of Milk and Honey, to the products of my Pauper Labor!"

did.unittitle: The Democratic Drug Store

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Text on document "Uncle Sam - "I'm not going to take that stuff - that Patent Medicine has been denounced and exposed by the whole American people. Hereafter I will get my prescriptions across the way."

did.unittitle: Loose pages from Puck and Judge

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains loose pages from Puck and Judge magazine. There are a wealth of advertisements and cartoons from the late 1800s and early 1900s. Many of the advertisements are for medicine and other medical treatments. Sometimes the loose pages are the center image from the magazine which is often a larger color political cartoon. Unfortunately, there is no order to these materials.
